main event: On April 2nd, 1952, a large silver unidentified object was observed hovering at a tremendous altitude over Lake Meade, Nevada. The object appeared to be similar in size to a B-36 bomber without wings and remained visible for about an hour before suddenly disappearing.
interesting points: The observation was made by a credible witness, M/Sgt, with twelve years of service in the Air Force and deemed highly reliable by his commanding officer.
The object was first noticed after the passage of B-54 aircraft, indicating a potential connection or interest in military aircraft.
No photographs were taken of the object, and no physical evidence was available to corroborate the sighting.
The object was described as silver, very large, and appeared to be at a considerably higher altitude than the surrounding vapor trails left by F-80 aircraft.
The location was reported to be at the eastern extremity of Lake Meade, Nevada, with clear weather conditions (CAVU).
witnesses: M/Sgt and wife, considered credible witnesses
